summary: This is the Amended and Restated Jeffrey E. Epstein 2019 Trust, dated February 4, 2019. It establishes a revocable trust with Epstein as Grantor and Darren K. Indyke and Richard D. Kahn as Trustees. The document details extensive bequests to numerous individuals upon Epstein's death, including large cash sums, annuities, and real property, and outlines complex trust structures for managing his assets.

persons.name: Jeffrey E. Epstein
persons.context: The creator and beneficiary of the trust during his lifetime, with extensive control over its terms and assets. He designates numerous bequests to individuals upon his death.

persons.name: Darren K. Indyke
persons.context: Named as a Trustee of the main trust and various sub-trusts. He is also a significant beneficiary, slated to receive $20 million and have certain debts forgiven.

persons.name: Richard D. Kahn
persons.context: Named as a Trustee of the main trust and various sub-trusts. He is also a significant beneficiary, slated to receive $20 million and have certain debts forgiven.

persons.name: Karyna Shuliak
persons.context: A primary beneficiary designated to receive $100 million, a $20 million annuity, multiple properties (Paris and Florida), and Epstein's diamonds. She is a contingent beneficiary for other assets.

persons.name: Eva Andersson Dubin
persons.context: Designated to receive the New York City property (9 E. 71st Street) and associated household goods.

persons.name: Michelle Fern Saipher
persons.context: Designated to receive $3 million for a specific real estate transaction repayment, contingent on being married to Darren Indyke. Also listed on Schedule B.

persons.name: Ann Rodriquez
persons.context: Designated to receive a $2 million annuity and have any outstanding debts to Epstein forgiven.

connections.description: Epstein is the Grantor and Indyke is a Trustee and long-time attorney/advisor. Indyke is also a major beneficiary and his debts are to be forgiven.
Epstein is the Grantor and Kahn is a Trustee and long-time attorney/advisor. Kahn is also a major beneficiary and his debts are to be forgiven.
Shuliak is the largest single beneficiary in the trust, set to receive $100 million cash, a $20 million annuity, multiple properties, and diamonds.
Saipher is referenced as Indyke's spouse in several bequest and debt-forgiveness provisions.
Lisa Kahn is referenced as Richard Kahn's spouse in debt-forgiveness provisions and is a Schedule B beneficiary.
Eileen Visoski is referenced as Lawrence Visoski's spouse in debt-forgiveness provisions.
Dubin is designated to receive the New York City property (9 E. 71st Street).
Groff is a beneficiary receiving $2 million and debt forgiveness, and also served as the notary for a trustee signature.
Co-Trustees of the Epstein trust, required to act unanimously on decisions.

events.title: Execution of Amended Trust
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein signs the Amended and Restated Jeffrey E. Epstein 2019 Trust, significantly updating a trust originally created on January 18, 2019.

events.title: Epstein's Death (Contingent Event)
events.description: The entire document outlines the complex financial and property distributions that are to occur upon the death of Jeffrey Epstein.

locations: Little St. James Island, St. Thomas, U.S. Virgin Islands (Epstein's residence)
49 Zorro Ranch Road, Stanley, New Mexico (Zorro Ranch)
Great St. James Island, U.S. Virgin Islands
358 El Brillo Way, Palm Beach, Florida
9 E. 71st Street, New York, New York
18 Teneyck Avenue, Valley Stream, New York
keyFacts: Jeffrey Epstein created this amended trust on February 4, 2019, less than six months before his death, maintaining full control over the assets during his lifetime.
Karyna Shuliak is the largest single beneficiary, slated to receive $100 million in cash, a $20 million annuity, properties in Paris and Palm Beach, and Epstein's diamond collection.
Trustees Darren Indyke and Richard Kahn are each designated to receive $20 million and have all their outstanding debts to Epstein's entities forgiven.
The trust includes a 'no contest' clause, disinheriting any beneficiary who challenges the validity of the trust or Epstein's will.
The document reveals a wide network of employees and associates receiving bequests ranging from $500,000 to $10 million, and has numerous redacted beneficiary names.
